  1. H⊂GH \subset GH⊂G. (HHH is a subset of GGG)
  2. eH=eGe_H = e_GeH​=eG​.

Subgroups are a natural extension of the notion of a subset to groups: they inherit the group's identity and binary operation while also inheriting a subset of its set. Examples of subgroups: (Z,+)(\mathbb{Z}, +)(Z,+) to (R,+)(\mathbb{R}, +)(R,+); (e,∗)(e, *)(e,∗), a group involving only the identity, to any group with the same operation ∗*∗ and identity eee; the group of divorced Hollywood actors to the group of Hollywood actors.

An easy way to check whether a given group is a subgroup of another is

Lemma. The subgroup lemma: let (G,⋅G,eG)(G, \cdot_G, e_G)(G,⋅G​,eG​) be a group and HHH be a non-empty subset of GGG. It is possible to find a unique binary operation ⋅H\cdot_H⋅H​ and an identity eHe_HeH​ such that H≤GH \leq GH≤G if and only if the following conditions are satisfied:

  1. eG∈He_G \in HeG​∈H.
  2. For any a,b∈Ha, b \in Ha,b∈H, a⋅Gb∈Ha \cdot_G b \in Ha⋅G​b∈H.
  3. For any a∈Ha \in Ha∈H, a−1∈Ha^{-1} \in Ha−1∈H.

Alternately, simply the condition that for any a,b∈Ha, b \in Ha,b∈H, the element a⋅Gb−1∈Ha \cdot_G b^{-1} \in Ha⋅G​b−1∈H suffices.

Proof.

The three given conditions are equivalent to stating that the four group axioms - closure, associativity, inverse, and identity - hold for HHH.

  1. Closure. Given by requirement (2) by definition.
  2. Associativity. Suppose that a,b,ca, b, ca,b,c are elements of HHH; as HHH is a subset of GGG, a,b,ca, b, ca,b,c are also elements of GGG, in which the binary operation ⋅G\cdot_G⋅G​ is associative. Thus, the associativity of ⋅G\cdot_G⋅G​ is inherited from GGG.
  3. Inverse. Given by requirement (3).
  4. Identity. Our requirement for HHH forming a subgroup is that HHH and GGG have the same identities. Denote the identity of a group formed by HHH as eHe_HeH​; then
    eH⋅GeH=eHe_H \cdot_G e_H = e_HeH​⋅G​eH​=eH​
    in the group HHH. In the group GGG, eHe_HeH​ has an inverse eH−1e_H^{-1}eH−1​ where eHeH−1=eGe_H e_H^{-1} = e_GeH​eH−1​=eG​, the identity of group GGG. Then
    eHeHeH−1=eHeH−1e_H e_H e_H^{-1} = e_H e_H^{-1}eH​eH​eH−1​=eH​eH−1​
    and as such
    eHeG=eGe_H e_G = e_GeH​eG​=eG​
    leading to eH=eGe_H = e_GeH​=eG​.

First, suppose that b=ab = ab=a (this element must exist as HHH is non-empty). Then we have a⋅Ga−1∈Ha \cdot_G a^{-1} \in Ha⋅G​a−1∈H, and as aaa is an element of GGG, a⋅a−1=eG∈Ha \cdot a^{-1} = e_G \in Ha⋅a−1=eG​∈H. This is equivalent to the first given condition.

Supposing that a=eGa = e_Ga=eG​, we have

eG⋅Gb−1=b−1∈He_G \cdot_G b^{-1} = b^{-1} \in HeG​⋅G​b−1=b−1∈H

if b∈Hb \in Hb∈H. This gives rise to the third condition, and leads directly to
